info.subtitle: HOWTOs about using Chinese in Debian

dedication.para: For all Debian Chinese Users and Developers.

preface.title: Foreword
preface.para: This Debian Chinese FAQ provides with suggestions and instructions about common problems and solutions when using Chinese under Debian.
We welcome suggestions around improving this document. Should you have any idea, please contact us via our maillist: debian-chinese-gb@lists.debian.org and debian-chinese-big5@lists.debian.org.
The document distributed with Debian package might be outdated. You may view the latest version of Debian Chinese FAQ online.

chapter.title: Overview of Chinese support in Debian
chapter.para: Chinese and eastern Asian language support on desktop Linux has improved greatly since 2000.
Debian follows the multilanguage support and specifications as other Linux distributions do. Things should work out-of-box under most circumstances.

However, to fully utilize the works of localization in Debian, you are suggested to use tasksel to select proper packages. Localization packages include input methods, translation packs, fonts, dictionaries, etc. Details will be explained below.

sect2.title: Using tasksel
sect2.para: As a beginning, you may initialize your Debian system by selecting the proper tasksel package during the installation process or after you finish it.

There are several tasks available for Chinese users, namely:
task-chinese-s task-chinese-s-desktop task-chinese-s-kde-desktop task-chinese-t task-chinese-t-desktop task-chinese-t-kde-desktop
After installation, you should already be able to read Chinese text from your Debian system. Typing Chinese might be a little more tricky, which will be explained in the following section.

sect2.title: Recommended Extra Packages
sect2.para: Here we list packages that may be useful to Chinese users. You may freely select any of them to fit your needs.

sect2.title: Setting correct locale
sect2.para: By setting up correct locale for your system, you may utilize all translated strings of applications and enjoy a Chinese interface.
We strongly encourage you to use the UTF-8 encoding. It is now the de-facto standard in the Linux world.
The traditional way is to use dpkg-reconfigure with superuser privilege: dpkg-reconfigure locales The modern way with systemd should use localectl:

chapter.title: Chinese Documents in Debian
chapter.para: Documents are provided by either software upstream or Debian itself. Debian cannot control whether certain software could provide with translated documents or not. However, there are some efforts specific to Debian that try to provide you with translated texts about software usage and things around Debian.
